questions.explanation: HDFS (Hadoop Distributed File System) is designed for storing large files across multiple machines.

questions.prompt: What is the primary advantage of distributed computing?
options: Process large datasets by dividing work across multiple nodes
questions.explanation: Distributed computing enables parallel processing of large datasets across multiple machines for scalability.

options: A programming model for processing large datasets in parallel
questions.explanation: MapReduce is a programming paradigm that divides tasks into Map (process) and Reduce (aggregate) phases.

questions.prompt: What is data replication in HDFS used for?
questions.explanation: HDFS replicates data blocks across multiple nodes to ensure availability if nodes fail.

questions.prompt: What is the typical block size in HDFS?
questions.explanation: HDFS uses large block sizes (typically 128 MB or 256 MB) optimized for large file storage and sequential access.

questions.prompt: What is the main advantage of Apache Spark over Hadoop MapReduce?
questions.explanation: Spark performs in-memory processing, making it much faster than disk-based MapReduce for iterative tasks.

questions.prompt: What is an RDD in Spark?
questions.explanation: RDD (Resilient Distributed Dataset) is Spark's fundamental data structure for distributed computation.

options: A centralized repository for storing structured and unstructured data at scale
questions.explanation: Data lakes store vast amounts of raw data in native format until needed, unlike structured data warehouses.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between a data lake and a data warehouse?
options: Lakes store raw data, warehouses store processed/structured data
questions.explanation: Data lakes store raw, unprocessed data while data warehouses contain structured, processed data for specific use cases.

questions.prompt: What does ETL stand for in data engineering?
questions.explanation: ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) is the process of extracting data from sources, transforming it, and loading into a target system.

title: Stream Processing and Big Data Workflows

options: Processing data in real-time as it arrives
questions.explanation: Stream processing analyzes and acts on data continuously as it flows, enabling real-time insights.

questions.prompt: Which technology is commonly used for stream processing?
questions.explanation: Apache Kafka is a distributed streaming platform for building real-time data pipelines and applications.

questions.prompt: What is the CAP theorem in distributed systems?
options: You can only guarantee 2 of 3: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance
questions.explanation: CAP theorem states distributed systems can only guarantee two of: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance.

questions.prompt: What is Apache Airflow used for?
questions.explanation: Apache Airflow orchestrates complex data workflows and pipelines through directed acyclic graphs (DAGs).

questions.prompt: What is horizontal scaling in big data systems?
options: Adding more machines to the cluster
questions.explanation: Horizontal scaling (scale-out) adds more nodes to the system, unlike vertical scaling which upgrades existing nodes.
